q: 's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness. Having worked with Jeff Immelt in the past, Steve Ballmer apparently wanted the world to know where he stands. He released the following statement on the Official Microsoft blog: Jeff Immelt and I started our careers together at Proctor& Gamble, and I have enormous respect for the success he's had at GE. He is an ideal business leader to chair the Barack Obama 's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness and help drive a focus on what we can all do to increase American competitiveness and create new jobs. Microsoft is all about some competitiveness lately, as evidenced by the company recently joining Fairsearch, the coalition ruffling Google's feathers over its pending acquisition of ITA Software. military for the future.( AP| KENNETH LAMBERT) to a reporter's question about whether there actually was evidence of any link between Saddam Hussein and terrorists seeking weapons of mass destruction. The Defense secretary responded: Reports that say that something hasn't happened are always interesting to me because, as we know, there are known knowns; there are things we know we know. We also know there are known unknowns; that is to say we know there are some things we do not know. But there are also unknown unknowns- the ones we don't know we don't know. It is, of course, a logical fallacy to multiply categories beyond necessity, but it's one Donald Rumsfeld has rhetorically mastered to create a self-conscious reputation as a fearless questioner of received truths, one he's

' that keeps me jazzed for "Idol.' It's an unhinged one," said Jim Cantiello about the entertaining, unpredictable shenanigans pulled out by Steven Tyler in the first two nights of audition episodes this week. Truth be told, I never realized how much I missed Paula[ Abdul] last year. Steven Tyler 's colorful language, zany metaphors and deafening jangly man-jewelry was just the entertaining wild card the two-night premiere needed to give it a must-see facelift. Jim Cantiello was glad that the new trio, which also includes sole returning judge Randy Jackson, didn"t fall into the same old "mean Simon Cowell " and "too-nice Paula" tropes. The next step is to reduce U.S. unemployment, an issue Barack Obama should make "the centerpiece" of his annual State of the Union address on Jan. 25, the former Cabinet member said. The American people are expecting him to say something about what he's going to do to keep the economy moving forward, Colin Powell said. Colin Powell has criticized his own party in recent months while supporting Barack Obama 's ultimately successful fight for Senate ratification of a new nuclear-arms-reduction treaty with Russia.
